Function Documentation

def give::run_assist (   toname = None  ) 

give-assist is ran here, it will use a c binary to elevate perms so that dirs can be made with the right perms safely

this way giver can: give, ungive, list files given taker can: take and list files to take

Parameters:
toname it is whomever is receiving the file

def give::run_copy (   frompath = None,
  topath = None,
  preserve = True 
)

this will copy the file from 'frompath' to 'topath' (givedir)

it makes sure the file exists in the frompath then copies.

Parameters:
frompath the directory where the file being given is located
topath the directory where the file will be copied to (givedir)
preserve if this is true, the timestamp is preserved on the giver's local file
Returns:
retcode from os calls to see if the file exists and copy

def give::fix_perms (   path = None  ) 

this fixes perms on the file.

it will use statbuf and chmod to change the perms, then it calls /bin/touch to update the new file's timestamp for the taker

Parameters:
path the path of the file given (givedir/.....)

def give::isokto (   prompt = None  ) 

this is ran if verbose option is used, it is interactive with the user it requires the user to type y or Y for yes, if anything else input it will take that as a no and return false

this is only ran if the the verbose option is passed in, it creates the interactivity

Parameters:
prompt this will be the question we are asking the user
Returns:
true if the user allows, false if not

def give::give_file (   fuid = None,
  tuid = None,
  path = None,
  prompt = False 
)

we call run_assist to help give the file, check to see if the file exists in the dir, then give the file using run_copy, finally change perms using fix_perms

Parameters:
fuid the givers's uid
tuid the taker's uid
path the location of the file the giver is giving
prompt if prompt is true that means verbose was enabled, this will run isokto

def give::ungive_file (   fuid = None,
  tuid = None,
  path = None,
  prompt = False 
)

this is almost the same as give, but will 'un-give' the file.

it uses os.unlink to delete the file in the givedir

Parameters:
tuid takers uid
fuid "un-giver's" uid
path the name of the file to be deleted
prompt if prompt is true that means verbose was enabled, this will run isokto, otherwise interactivity isn't enabled
Returns:
1 for success

def give::take_file (   fuid = None,
  tuid = None,
  path = None,
  prompt = False 
)

this will take the file and copy it into the taker's current directory if the copy is successful, it will delete the file from the givedir using os.unlink

Parameters:
fuid the giver's uid
tuid the taker's uid
path the file to be 'taken'
prompt if prompt is true that means verbose was enabled, this will run isokto, otherwise intractivity isn't enabled

def give::enumerate_files (   f = None,
  t = None 
)

this is used to generate the list of files in the directories, or enumerate the files to be listed

Parameters:
f the giver usrname
t the taker usrname
Returns:
dlist the list of files in the directory spool/taker/from

def give::list_a_file (   path = None,
  brief = False 
)

this is used to list a file, to do this os.path.basename is used on the path.

if brief is true then the name of the file is listed, if brief is false then the size of the file is listed, along with the timestamp

Parameters:
path the file to be listed, it includes the full path
brief this is used to determine what info is printed.

def give::list_a_directory (   path = None,
  brief = False,
  header = None 
)

this will list a directory which is path, it cals list_a_file to list the files in the path.

Parameters:
path the directory that will be listed
brief passed into list_a_file see that param section
header this is printed above the files in the directory, it says (user has given:)
Returns:
the amount of files in the dir

def give::get_giverpw_from_dir (   giver = None,
  taker = None 
)

in the case we have no getpwnam() data for a giver, we attempt to fake it from data in the directory.

Parameters:
giver giver's username
taker taker's username

def give::list_files_given (   myuid = None,
  theiruid = None,
  brief = False 
)

list the files you have given, this is invoked if give is ran w/o params.

it uses os.listdir on spool, then sorts the subdirs and calls list_a_directory to list the files. It

Parameters:
myuid this is the username of the invoking user
theiruid this is the username of the person that was given the file
brief this will determine if it tells the amount of files given

def give::list_files_totake (   myuid = None,
  theiruid = None,
  brief = False 
)

list the files to take, it calls list a directory to assist with this, it is invoked if take is ran w/o params.

it usees os.listdir on spool/myuid to be able to see what subdirs/files have been given, it prints the name, size, and who gave the file.

Parameters:
myuid 
theiruid 
brief 

def give::validate_transaction (   giver_uname,
  taker_uname 
)

We validate various things that should be true-.

1) taker/giver usernames map to available users (we can look them up)

2) if group "gt-<taker uid>" exists, then the giver is a member

3) taker's group exists, and the taker is the ONLY member

Parameters:
giver_uname giver's username
taker_uname taker's username

Variable Documentation

int give::STRICT = 1 [static]

STRICT will be set to 0 if non-strict checking was enabled at config time, or 1 by default (if non-strict checking wasn't enabled).

string give::SPOOL = "/usr/givedir" [static]

SPOOL will be set to /usr/givedir at config time, unless .

/config --enable-givedir=DIR is passed in at config time, then the SPOOL = DIR
